questions.text: A diabetic patient was advised exercise by the treating physician. The glucose transporter which is insulin sensitive is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glut 4

 

Glucose transporter 4 (Glut 4) is the insulin-sensitive glucose transporter found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle. Insulin plays a key role in regulating glucose uptake in these tissues by promoting the translocation of Glut 4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane, thereby enhancing glucose entry into the cell. This insulin-mediated mechanism is crucial in maintaining blood glucose levels, especially during states of increased energy demand, such as exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glut 1: This glucose transporter is found in nearly all tissues, including the brain, and facilitates the basal uptake of glucose independently of insulin. It is not insulin-sensitive.

 

Option B. Glut 2: Glut 2 is mainly present in liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the renal tubules, where it helps regulate glucose levels.

 

Option C. Glut 3: This transporter is primarily located in neurons and the placenta, ensuring high-affinity glucose uptake in tissues with high glucose demand. It is not regulated by insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glut 4 is the only glucose transporter that is insulin-sensitive, primarily found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle, where it facilitates glucose uptake in response to insulin.

questions.text: In a small coastal town in Kerala, a sudden surge of gastroenteritis cases is reported within two days after a community seafood feast. Health officials suspect the seafood feast as the source of the epidemic. Which of the following statements is true regarding this type of single exposure point source epidemic? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Explosive in nature

 

Single exposure or ‘Point source’ epidemics characteristics:

 

  • ‘Sharp rise and sharp fall’ in no. of cases i.e., single wave 
  • ‘Clustering of cases’ in a narrow interval of time
  • All ‘cases develop within one incubation period’ of the disease.
  • Examples: Food poisoning, Measles, Chicken pox, Cholera, BHOPAL GAS TRAGEDY

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. With more than 1 incubation period: Incorrect as single exposure epidemics are confined to one incubation period.

 

Option C. With multiple peaks: Incorrect as single exposure epidemics typically have a single peak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single exposure point source epidemics are explosive in nature with a rapid increase and decline in cases, confined to one incubation period.

questions.text: What of the following stain can be used for staining Iron in tissues? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prussian blue  

 

Perl's iron stain is the classic method for demonstrating iron in tissues. The section is treated with dilute hydrochloric acid to release ferric ions from binding proteins. These ions then react with potassium ferrocyanide to produce an insoluble blue compound (the Prussian blue reaction).

 

 

Used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, lead toxicity to visualize iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts and myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Masson's trichrome: This stain is used to differentiate between collagen and other tissue components. It stains collagen fibers blue or green, muscle fibers red, and cytoplasm light red or pink. It is not used for detecting iron.

 

Option C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): PAS stain is primarily used to detect glycogen and other polysaccharides in tissues. It stains these components magenta. PAS is not useful for detecting iron in tissues.

 

Option D. Fite-Faraco: This is a special stain used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium responsible for leprosy. It is not used for staining iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussian blue stain is specifically used for detecting iron deposits in tissues, particularly in cases of iron overload or iron-related disorders.

questions.text: Fluid of choice for elective surgery is preferably: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crystalloid

 

Crystalloids are aqueous solutions of mineral salts or other water-soluble molecules. Common crystalloids include normal saline and lactated Ringer's solution. They are the preferred choice for fluid resuscitation in elective surgery due to their availability, cost-effectiveness, and safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood: Blood transfusions are generally reserved for cases of significant blood loss where the patient's blood volume or hemoglobin levels are critically low. It is not the fluid of choice for routine elective surgery as it carries risks of transfusion reactions, infections, and immunological effects.

 

Option B. Colloid: Colloids (like albumin, dextrans, gelatins) are high molecular weight solutions that can stay in the vascular compartment longer than crystalloids. They are used to manage hypovolemia due to their volume expansion effect. However, they are more expensive and have not shown superiority over crystalloids in numerous studies.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): FFP is used to correct coagulation abnormalities, not as a fluid of choice for hydration or volume expansion in elective surgery. It is indicated when there is a deficiency of coagulation factors, such as in disseminated intravascular coagulation or massive transfusion protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred fluid for elective surgery is crystalloid due to its efficacy in volume expansion, safety, and cost-effectiveness compared to blood, colloid, or FFP.

questions.text: 2 hours after watching a movie, a patient presented with eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol + Pilocarpine

 

The scenario described is indicative of an acute angle-closure glaucoma attack, which commonly occurs when a person with a shallow anterior chamber enters a dark environment, such as a movie theater. In the dark, the pupil dilates, and the iris moves peripherally, leading to blockage of the trabecular meshwork and subsequently increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition requires urgent management to prevent damage to the optic nerve.

 

Mannitol, a hyperosmotic agent, is administered to quickly reduce the vitreous volume by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby decreasing IOP. This reduction in vitreous volume allows the lens and iris to move backward, alleviating the blockage of the trabecular meshwork. After the IOP is reduced, Pilocarpine, a miotic agent, is given to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle closure, helping to maintain the IOP at a safer level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mannitol + Moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections. It has no role in the management of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Option C. Mannitol + Atropine: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, which would worsen the condition by increasing angle closure. Therefore, it is contraindicated in this scenario.

 

Option D. Mannitol + lubricating eye drops: Lubricating eye drops only provide surface moisture and have no effect on intraocular pressure or the underlying mechanism of angle closure, making them ineffective in this emergency situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line management of acute angle-closure glaucoma involves the use of Mannitol to reduce intraocular pressure followed by Pilocarpine to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle obstruction.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease," is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It is more common in young Asian females under 40 years old. The clinical presentation includes claudication (typically in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery involvement), weak pulses (particularly in the extremities), and symptoms resulting from ischemia in various organs (e.g., transient loss of vision due to carotid or vertebral artery involvement, abdominal pain due to mesenteric artery involvement).

 

The combination of weak femoral pulses, claudication in the forearm, and retinal hemorrhages is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis. This condition can lead to narrowing or occlusion of major arteries, causing diminished blood flow to the affected regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause abdominal pain, claudication, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically affect the large vessels and therefore would not explain the weak femoral pulses. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B. Thromboangiitis obliterans: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) typically affects young male smokers and primarily involves the small and medium arteries of the extremities. It can cause claudication and ischemic symptoms in the limbs but does not typically cause weak femoral pulses or retinal hemorrhages.

 

Option D. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that often presents with symptoms related to kidney and lung involvement (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage). It does not typically present with claudication or weak pulses in the large vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

questions.text: Mother had painful vesicular lesions over genitalia one year back. Baby is born with features of meningitis and fever and rashes in abdomen and forearm and died within a week. Scrapings from lesions showed multinucleate giant cells. What is the most likely organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2)

 

Explanation

 

  • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection.
  • The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2.
  • Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection.
  • The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes.
  • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterovirus 70:

 

  • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question.
  • It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis.
  • HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.

 

Option D. VZV:

 

  • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.

questions.text: Aspartate forms which of the following intermediate of TCA cycle:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxaloacetate

 

Aspartate can be converted into oxaloacetate through transamination. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate aminotransferase (AST). Oxaloacetate is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle and is also involved in gluconeogenesis. It can condense with acetyl-CoA to form citrate, thus participating in the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Citrate: Citrate is the first intermediate of the TCA cycle, formed by the condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate. Aspartate does not directly form citrate. Instead, citrate is generated through the actions of citrate synthase at the beginning of the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Alpha-Keto Glutarate: Alpha-ketoglutarate is an intermediate in the TCA cycle, but it is not directly formed from aspartate. It is produced from isocitrate through oxidative decarboxylation. Although aspartate can feed into the production of other TCA cycle intermediates, it does not directly convert into alpha-ketoglutarate.

 

Option D. Glutamate: Glutamate is an amino acid and not an intermediate of the TCA cycle. Although it is involved in amino acid metabolism and can undergo transamination reactions with various compounds, it is not a direct product of aspartate metabolism in the context of the TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspartate an amino acid can be converted to oxaloacetate, an intermediate of the cycle. The conversion of aspartate to oxaloacetate is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate transaminase.

 

 

Therefore, aspartate forms glutamate as an intermediate in the TCA cycle.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 160

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Pseudo P pulmonale, characterized by exaggerated amplitude in the P wave, can be observed on an ECG in the context of hypokalemia. This electrolyte disturbance affects cardiac electrophysiology, leading to various changes including prolonged QT interval, presence of U waves, T wave flattening or inversion, and sometimes pseudo-infarction patterns, which can mimic myocardial infarction.

 

Hypokalemia can result in these distinct ECG changes due to its influence on cellular membrane potentials in cardiac cells, which alters the normal propagation of electrical impulses through the myocardium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Does not typically cause prominent P wave changes; its ECG manifestations are less specific and often involve general effects on conduction and contractility.

 

Note - Hyponatremia is usually silent on the ECG

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Associated with prolonged QT interval due to an elongation of the ST segment but not with pseudo P pulmonale.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: Typically presents with a shortened QT interval and shortened ST segment, differing significantly from the changes seen in hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cardiac oedema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with cardiac edema and neuropathy. The deficiency of thiamine can manifest in two main forms:

 

  • Wet beriberi: This form of thiamine deficiency primarily affects the cardiovascular system. It is characterized by symptoms such as tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. This condition is commonly observed in populations with diets heavily based on polished rice, such as in refugee camps.
  • Dry beriberi: This form affects the nervous system and includes symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

 

Thiamine deficiency can also lead to complications such as lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults. The diagnosis can be established by assessing erythrocyte transketolase activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin deficiency is rare and can be observed in individuals who consume large amounts of raw eggs (which contain avidin that binds biotin) for several months. Symptoms include anorexia, vomiting, dry scaly dermatitis, glossitis, and hypercholesterolemia. It can also occur in patients receiving long-term parenteral nutrition without biotin supplementation.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency in pyridoxine is associated with neonatal seizures and other symptoms such as dermatitis, glossitis, and depression, but not specifically with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency in riboflavin, known as ariboflavinosis, presents with photophobia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, and cataracts, but not with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is characterized by cardiac edema and neuropathy, manifesting as wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms) and dry beriberi (neurological symptoms).

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Thirst

 

Thirst is recognized as the most reliable feature of some dehydration. When dehydration begins to set in, the body's initial response is to signal thirst as a way to encourage fluid intake. This response is consistent across various cases of mild to moderate dehydration. Unlike other symptoms, thirst is a direct and early indicator of dehydration that can be easily recognized by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: Skin turgor, or the delayed return of the skin to its normal position after being pinched, is influenced by several factors, including nutritional status. This makes it less reliable as a sole indicator of dehydration.

 

Option B. Lethargy: Lethargy can be a symptom of dehydration, but it is difficult to quantify and may vary widely depending on the individual's overall health and the severity of dehydration.

 

Option D. Sunken eyes: The appearance of sunken eyes is quite subjective and often requires the input of a caregiver, such as a parent, to determine whether it is present. It is also not always a definitive sign of dehydration, making it less reliable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bromocriptine

 

Explanation:

 

The choice of dopamine agonist therapy for hyperprolactinemia in patients desiring fertility remains somewhat controversial. Advanced textbooks such as "Speroff's Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility" clearly highlight that cabergoline has greater potency, fewer side effects, better tolerability, and convenient dosing compared to bromocriptine, leading to its general preference for prolactinoma treatment.

 

However, Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine (21st Edition) explicitly mentions:

 

“Because cabergoline is long-acting with a high D₂-receptor affinity, it is not recommended for use in women when fertility is desired.”

 

Considering the context of Indian postgraduate entrance examinations, it is advisable to adhere to Harrison's recommendations. Therefore, although cabergoline is generally considered superior, bromocriptine is the safer and recommended answer for this specific examination scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cabergoline: Although generally preferred for routine prolactinoma management, it is explicitly not recommended during conception planning as per Harrison’s.

 

Option C. Octreotide: A somatostatin analog indicated exclusively for GH-secreting tumors, not prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: A GH receptor antagonist used specifically in acromegaly, with no role in prolactinoma or fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian PG entrance examinations, bromocriptine remains the recommended first-line treatment in women with microprolactinoma who desire fertility, despite cabergoline’s clinical advantages, based on guidelines explicitly mentioned in Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to make an "OK" sign is typically caused by a lesion of the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. This nerve innervates three muscles, including the flexor pollicis longus (FPL), which is responsible for flexing the thumb. When the FPL is affected, the patient cannot flex the distal phalanx of the thumb, resulting in an inability to form the "OK" sign with their hand. The term "Kiloh-Nevin sign" is used to describe this clinical finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle abducts the thumb and is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb for the "OK" sign.

 

Option C. Lumbricals: These muscles flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. They are not involved in making the "OK" sign.

 

Option D. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the fingers, but it does not contribute directly to the flexion of the thumb required for the "OK" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor pollicis longus is essential for making the "OK" sign, and its impairment is a key clinical feature of anterior interosseous nerve damage.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of variation

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is used to compare the relative variability of different datasets. It is a standardized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution. The CV is particularly useful because it expresses the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, making it possible to compare the degree of variation from one dataset to another, regardless of the unit of measurement or magnitude of the mean.

 

  • Co-efficient of Variation [COV] = SD/Mean x 100
  • It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance measures the spread of a set of numbers. It is the average of the squared differences from the mean. While it indicates variability, it does not provide a standardized measure for comparison between different datasets.

 

Option C. Standard Error of Mean (SEM): The SEM measures how much the sample mean of the data is likely to vary from the true population mean. It is used to understand the accuracy of the sample mean but is not used for comparing variability between datasets.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation (SD): Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. While it indicates the spread of data points, it does not standardize this measure in relation to the mean, which is necessary for comparing different datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Global Hunger Index? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Infant Mortality Rate

 

Explanation:

 

The Global Hunger Index is calculated based on the following indicators:

 

Till 2014 – following 3 indicators

 

 

After 2016, the Global Hunger Index calculation was done using above four indicators, which do not include the infant mortality rate directly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. U5MR: Because the under-five mortality rate is one of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Option B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting): Because both child wasting and child stunting are part of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Option C. Inadequate food supply: Because, while inadequate food supply can contribute to child undernourishment, it is not directly used as an indicator in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index is calculated using four indicators: child undernourishment, under-five mortality rate, child wasting, and child stunting. The infant mortality rate is not directly included in the calculation.

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is commonly used in neurosurgery and microsurgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nylon

 

Nylon is a non-absorbable suture material and is commonly used in neurosurgery, microsurgery, and ophthalmic surgery due to its low tissue reaction and high tensile strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyglactin: Polyglactin (Vicryl) is an absorbable braided suture material and is commonly used in general surgical practices for gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures, subcuticular wound closures, and ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option C. Polypropylene 1-0 & Option D. Polypropylene 2-0: Polypropylene is a non-absorbable suture material and is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair. Polypropylene 1-0 and 2-0 refer to the size or diameter of the suture, with 1-0 being larger than 2-0. These sutures are too thick to be used in microsurgery.

 

Therefore, options B, C, and D are incorrect as they do not match the given description.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for her postpartum checkup. She mentions that she has been exclusively breastfeeding her newborn and is concerned about meeting her own nutritional needs in order to ensure the best for her baby. She asks you about specific nutrient supplementation she might need during this period of lactation. Compared to her pregnancy, which nutrient would you recommend she should pay particular attention to increasing? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Vitamin A

 

  • The requirement for Vitamin A increases during lactation more than during pregnancy.
  • Vitamin A is essential for ensuring the quality of breast milk, which is the sole source of nutrition for a newborn.
  • It plays a critical role in the development of the baby’s immune system and visual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,

 

  • Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron
  • Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium
  • Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium

questions.text: The drug used in chemoradiation in cervical cancer:  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cisplatin

 

In the treatment of cervical cancer, chemoradiation is a standard approach, particularly for stages beyond 2A where surgery may not be feasible.

 

Chemoradiation combines chemotherapy and radiation therapy to enhance the effectiveness of treatment.

 

Cisplatin is the drug of choice because it acts as a radiosensitizer. This means. that cisplatin makes the cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation therapy, thereby increasing the overall efficacy of the treatment. The standard regimen involves administering cisplatin concurrently with external beam radiotherapy, and this may be followed by internal beam radiotherapy to maximize treatment impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Used in various chemotherapy regimens but not as a primary radiosensitizer in cervical cancer chemoradiation.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases but not primarily in cervical cancer chemoradiation.

 

Option C. Actinomycin D: Used in the treatment of certain pediatric cancers and other malignancies but not as a standard radiosensitizer in cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisplatin is the preferred drug used in chemoradiation for cervical cancer because it acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of radiation therapy.

questions.text: Organisms entering via enteric route into our body are countered by which cells of the liver? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kupffer cells

 

Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages of the liver that are responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies.

 

Pathogenesis

 

Organisms

           ↓

         Enteric Route

           ↓

       Portal Vein

           ↓

           Liver

           ↓

    Kupffer Cells (Liver Macrophages)

           ↓

   Phagocytosis and Destruction

           ↓

 Activation of Immune Response

           ↓

Recruitment of Other Immune Cells

           ↓

  Clearance of Pathogens

           ↓

  Prevention of Dissemination

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dust cells: These are alveolar macrophages found in the lungs.

 

Option C. Ito cells: These cells are concerned with the storage of vitamin A and are located in the liver.

 

Option D. Mesangial cells: These cells are found in the kidneys and support glomerular capillaries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kupffer cells are the liver macrophages responsible for countering organisms entering the body via the enteric route.

choices.text: Pain in both active and passive movements

questions.text: Non-articular bone pain is differentiated from articular bone pain by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in only active movements

 

ARTICULAR VS NON-ARTICULAR PAIN

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-articular pain occurs only during active movements. When both active and passive range of movements are painful, it is due to articular pain.

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

questions.text: Name the investigation shown in the given image?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

 

Hysterosalpingography

 

  • Hysterosalpingography is the fluoroscopic examination commonly used in the investigations of infertility to assess uterine morphology and tubal patency.
  • The best time to investigate is during the 6th to 10th day of menstrual cycle (not to be done during menstruation; risk of damage to undiagnosed pregnancy after 10th day)
  • A radiopaque dye is injected through the Leech-Wilkinson or Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter into the uterine cavity under direct vision with fluoroscopic screen.
  • If the tubes are patent, the medium is usually adequate to exit through the abdominal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR HSG: Involves the use of magnetic resonance imaging to view the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes, not compatible with the use of traditional radiopaque dyes and does not involve real-time fluoroscopy.

 

Option B. CT HSG: Utilizes computed tomography, which is less common and not shown in the image due to the distinct fluoroscopic appearance of conventional HSG.

 

Option D. USG HSG: Ultrasound HSG, also known as sonohysterography, uses ultrasound technology to evaluate the uterus and fallopian tubes, which would not display the classic radiopaque dye pattern seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conventional HSG is a critical diagnostic tool in the assessment of uterine structure and tubal patency, using a radiopaque dye visualized with fluoroscopy, particularly useful in the workup of infertility.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

 

Explanation:

 

The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.

 

 

Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ

 

IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop, which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst. It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.

 

Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for 4 months. Her ALP levels are elevated, but serum calcium and phosphorus levels are normal, and X-ray of the patient is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's Disease

 

Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and weakening of bones. The most commonly affected areas include the pelvis, skull, spine, and legs. In Paget's disease, the process of bone remodeling is disrupted, leading to an imbalance between the breakdown and formation of bone tissue. This results in the formation of structurally abnormal bone, which can cause pain, deformities, and an increased risk of fractures.

 

In this case, the patient presents with bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, which are characteristic findings of Paget's disease. The X-ray showing multiple small spots and thickening of the calvarium is also typical of Paget's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects younger individuals and presents with localized bone pain and swelling. It is associated with elevated ALP but usually involves more aggressive bone destruction and periosteal reaction on imaging.

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It presents with pain and swelling and is associated with a characteristic "onion skin" appearance on X-ray. The patient's age and the X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that usually presents as a painless, palpable mass near the ends of long bones in adolescents and young adults. It does not typically present with elevated ALP or the described X-ray findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of bone is characterized by bone pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels, with characteristic X-ray findings such as thickening of the calvarium

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dicloxacillin

 

Explanation:

 

Beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins are recommended in the treatment of mastitis. These include cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, or flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive. Dicloxacillin is often the first choice due to its effectiveness against the common causative organism, Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Puerperal Mastitis:

 

  • Definition: Mastitis is an inflammatory condition of the breast that may occur in breastfeeding women during the puerperium.
  • Pathogenesis: Infants are inoculated by personnel carrying S. aureus and transmit the bacteria to the breastfeeding mother through the nasopharynx.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Maternal age > 30 years
    • Maternal fatigue and stress
    • Sores and cracked nipples
    • History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy
    • Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis
  • Etiology:
    • Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus.
    • Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher)
    • Chills, myalgia, malaise
    • Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral
    • Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration
    • Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound
    • Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis
  • Treatment:
    • Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin
    • Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin
    • Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms
    • Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess
    • Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cefazolin: While cefazolin is a cephalosporin and can be effective, it is not the first-line treatment compared to dicloxacillin for mastitis.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is typically used for more severe infections and is not the first-line treatment for mastitis.

 

Option D. Ampicillin: Ampicillin may be used but is not as effective as dicloxacillin for treating Staphylococcus aureus infections in mastitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicloxacillin is the first-line treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers, especially effective against Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Ref: https://www.glowm.com/section-view/heading/Puerperal%20Mastitis/item/142

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The ECG shows a case of atrial fibrillation, characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves. Instead, there are fibrillatory waves that can be seen in the baseline. Atrial fibrillation is a common type of irregular heart rhythm where the atria beat chaotically and irregularly.

 

Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It is primarily indicated for the treatment of regular narrow complex tachycardias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can help reset the heart rhythm in cases of regular tachycardias. However, in irregular rhythms like atrial fibrillation, adenosine is contraindicated because it can induce atrial fibrillation or exacerbate the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It helps control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the AV node.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation. It can help to convert atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm and maintain it.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by slowing conduction through the AV node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male was brought to OPD by his mother with reduced hearing since 2 months. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane was observed as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Myringitis Bullosa

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous otitis media: (glue ear) cases present with hearing loss and mild ear ache. Otoscopy reveals fluid level and air bubbles.

 

 

Option B. Acute otitis media: Patients present with ear ache, fever, ear discharge. Following image shows red and bulging TM.

 

 

Option D. Myringitis Granulosa: Patient usually presents with painless otorrhea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis Bullosa should be considered when a patient presents with the acute onset of ear pain accompanied by visible blisters on the tympanic membrane, particularly in the context of a recent upper respiratory infection or influenza-like illness. Management focuses on pain relief and monitoring for resolution, with antibiotics or antivirals tailored to the underlying cause if identified.

questions.text: Patient had a fall on Outstretched hand. He presented with Fracture and displacement of Base of 1st metacarpal. This fracture is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bennet’s fracture 

 

  • A Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, which is associated with displacement due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. 

 

 

  • This type of fracture typically occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury). 
  • The mechanism of injury and the specific displacement due to muscle pull are characteristic of Bennett's fracture.
  • The shaft of the metacarpal is laterally dislocated by the unopposedpull of the abductor pollicis longus. 
  • The medial projection of the metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches remains in place. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scaphoid fracture: A scaphoid fracture is common in young adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it involves the scaphoid bone in the wrist, not the base of the first metacarpal.

 

 

Option C. Rolando fracture: This is also an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal (T or Y) but involves comminution without displacement.

 

 

Option D. Colles fracture: A Colles' fracture is a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement, commonly seen in older adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it does not involve the first metacarpal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

questions.text: True about Warburg effect?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation

 

This is the correct statement. The Warburg effect is characterized by cancer cells utilizing glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen (aerobic glycolysis), leading to the production of lactate. This metabolic shift is a hallmark of many cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Makes cancer cells immortal: This statement is not true. The Warburg effect is a metabolic phenomenon observed in many cancer cells where they preferentially use glycolysis to generate energy, but it does not make cancer cells immortal. Immortality of cancer cells is typically associated with mutations that allow them to evade normal cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.

 

Option C. Produce more ATP: This statement is not true in the context of the Warburg effect. While glycolysis is less efficient at producing ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation (which occurs in the mitochondria), cancer cells under the Warburg effect primarily generate ATP through glycolysis, which is less efficient but provides other metabolic advantages to rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Option D. Decrease glucose uptake: This statement is not true. Cancer cells under the Warburg effect often increase their glucose uptake to meet their high energy demands through glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warburg effect

 

  • This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O2. This is known as aerobic glycolysis.
  • Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs, hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 738

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker of carcinoid tumor? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-HIAA

 

Carcinoid tumors originate from enterochromaffin cells, which are rich in serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). Serotonin is metabolized to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine are indicative of a carcinoid tumor, particularly when the tumor is active and producing excessive serotonin. This makes 5-HIAA a reliable tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring carcinoid tumors and the associated carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin is a tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, not carcinoid tumors. It is used to monitor patients with medullary thyroid cancer.

 

Option C. Catecholamine: Catecholamines are associated with adrenal medullary tumors, such as pheochromocytoma. They are not specific for carcinoid tumors.

 

Option D. Dopamine: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter and is not used as a tumor marker for carcinoid tumors. It is associated with different physiological and pathological processes, but not directly with carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinically, patients with carcinoid syndrome may present with a range of symptoms including hepatomegaly, bronchospasm that mimics asthma, episodes of vasoconstriction affecting blood vessels, increased intestinal motility manifesting as diarrhea, and distinctive flushing of the skin. The co-occurrence of symptoms like diarrhea, asthma-like respiratory issues, and hepatomegaly should immediately suggest the possibility of carcinoid syndrome.

 

An increase in the levels of 5-HIAA in blood and urine is a significant indicator (primary tumor marker) of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A young male child presents with failure to pass meconium and has been diagnosed with megacolon. Which of the following layers is affected by the absence of neurons? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

The patient is likely suffering from Hirschsprung disease, a condition caused by the absence of enteric nerve plexuses due to a failure of migration of neural crest cells. This absence affects the submucosal (Meissner's) plexus and the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus, which are located in the submucosa (Layer 2) and the muscularis propria (Layer 3), respectively. The lack of these plexuses results in a failure of peristalsis and subsequent megacolon, as the affected segment of the colon cannot properly relax and move bowel contents forward.

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Layer 1 and 4: Layers 1 and 4 correspond to the mucosa and serosa, neither of which contain the affected neural plexuses seen in Hirschsprung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of the submucosal (Meissner's) and myenteric (Auerbach's) plexuses in the submucosa and muscularis propria, leading to functional obstruction and megacolon due to failure of neural crest cell migration.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Secondary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Explanation   

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

 

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

 

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.

 

Option B. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.

 

Option C. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: Elderly male with a 3-week presents with history of trauma, with CT brain image as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SDH (Subdural Hematoma)

 

The correct diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma (SDH). In elderly patients with a history of trauma, a sub-acute subdural hematoma often presents with symptoms that develop gradually over weeks due to slow venous bleeding. The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped (banana-shaped) hyperdense area, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma. The chronic nature of the subdural hematoma is suggested by the time course (3 weeks’ post-trauma) and is more common in the elderly due to brain atrophy, which increases the risk of bridging vein tears leading to SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH (Epidural Hematoma): An epidural hematoma typically presents with a biconvex (lens-shaped) appearance on CT imaging, occurring between the skull and the dura mater. It is often associated with a more acute presentation following head trauma, usually involving arterial bleeding, and is less common in the elderly unless there is a direct skull fracture involving the middle meningeal artery.

 

Option C. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage): A subarachnoid hemorrhage presents as hyperdensity in the basal cisterns, sulci, or along the surface of the brain on CT. It is most commonly associated with ruptured aneurysms and would not present with a crescent or banana-shaped lesion as seen in the provided CT image.

 

Option D. Contusion: A contusion would show localized areas of bleeding or edema within the brain tissue itself, often with a mixed density appearance due to the presence of both hemorrhage and edema. Contusions do not have the crescent shape seen with SDH.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is often seen in elderly patients with a history of minor trauma, presenting weeks after the injury with symptoms such as headache, confusion, or neurological deficits. The characteristic CT finding is a crescent-shaped collection along the convexity of the brain, distinguishing it from other types of intracranial hemorrhages.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Constricted pupils and bradycardia

 

Dilated pupils and tachycardia is seen with cocaine ingestion as it is a sympathomimetic (stimulant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling and numbness of hands and feet: This is a common symptom due to the neurological effects of cocaine.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Cocaine causes vasoconstriction and increased heart rate, leading to hypertension.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: Increased body temperature is a common finding due to excessive sympathetic stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of cocaine intoxication:

 

  • Early features – Stage of excitement:
  • Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
  • Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death.
  • Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin.
  • Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

A. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

 

 

B. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.

 

C. Anterior: In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.

 

D. Posterior: This is the least common type. In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common > central type > anterior type > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).
  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of  neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Psoas abscess can give rise to pseudo-hip flexion deformity
  • Paraplegia occurs most often in upper thoracic region.∙
  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • Sequelae of TB spine is usually bony ankylosis.

 

  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph: 
    • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: 
    • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
       
  • MRI:
    • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
    • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

  • Biopsy:
    • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

 

  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: no neural complaint; increased reflexes
    • Stage 2: weakness but can walk with support
    • Stage 3: non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%
    • Stage 4: bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%
       
       
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exists  then, surgery needs to be done.
    • Stage-wise Treatment:
      • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
      • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
      • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
      • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
         
    • ATT: 
      • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
      • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
         
    • Indications of surgery: 
      • Bowel bladder involvement
      • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
      • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
         
  • Surgical options for most of the cases aren anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed)

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
     

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.
